episode.title: Northern Pacific Railway Company v. United States

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: -- what I was saying at adjournment yesterday afternoon, Northern Pacific land grant amounted to approximately 39 and a half million acres.
All of this acreage has at all times been for sale and as fast as the sentence could be induced to the company and as purchasers could be found, the land had been sold.
So that at the time the complaint was filed in May, 1949, the company had sold all but approximately 2,700,000 acres.
In the sales of these lands, the traffic clauses were ever used where the lands were agriculture in character or were grazing lands.
But in the case of lands which were valuable solely for their natural resources such as timber, minerals, coal and iron and the like.
Traffic clauses were used from the beginning of the character that I have explained.
Because those natural resources had a special value to the Northern Pacific and not to obtainable market price and that Northern Pacific have a transportation agency.
It had railroad to transport these commodities to market to resume the transportation business.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: May I ask you Mr. Countryman?
What is the relationship between the Northern Pacific Railway Company and the Northwestern Improvement Company?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: The Northwestern Improvement is wholly on subsidiary.

Originally incorporated under the laws of New Jersey and later transferred to Delaware, it's organized as a New Jersey corporation in 1897 to takeover lands that were subject to Missouri division mortgage of the old company in order to keep them up to (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Are all the lands of the Northern Pacific Railway Company of this character in -- in the ownership of the Improvement Company?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor, relatively small proportion of the lands are in ownership of the Improvement Company.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Why -- why is the differentiation?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: The Improvement Company took over only these lands that were subject to the Missouri division mortgage.
Those were in -- principally in North Dakota and they're practically old and sold to agricultural lands.
Very little remained in Northwestern Improvement Company ownership although I think the Improvement Company did have some timberlands in Montana.
And as I've stated to yesterday, the Improvement Company has at all times has been treated as the department of the railroad.
The land department of the railroad is the land department of the Improvement Company.
And this -- well it doesn't appear in the record, we are now in the process of dissolving the Improvement Company.

Of the lands that had been sold, only 2,144,000 acres were timberlands subject to traffic clauses and all but about 218,000 acres of that 2,144,000 were sold prior to 1910, 900,000 acres were sold to warehouses in 1900 and the traffic clauses in that contract expired in 1915.
The Railway Company as I say had an interest in land -- in the natural resources and when the lands containing coal or iron which I might say were included in the grant were sold.
Generally, the minerals were accepted and reserved to the company.

If other minerals were suspected to be present, a reservation of minerals is also made so that in 1949, the Railway Company had about -- had mineral rates in about six and a half million acres of land.
In all leases of it are mineral rights or timberlands or cutting timber or for removal of natural resources.
They have included the traffic clause providing that the lessee with ship products over our line upon which were equal to those of any competitors and when the destination to be reached by our land.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Are the -- are the clauses coterminous with the periods of the leases?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: I beg Pardon?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Are the clauses, the traffic clauses coterminous with the leases?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Are these clauses peculiar to your railroad or at the same time the clauses found another --

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
They are very general among railroads.
They have been used for 75 years I would say.
There are quite a number of cases of the books, where the reasonableness or the validity of traffic clauses of this character had been before the Court.
Only a few have involved to questions of violation of the antitrust laws.
They have been uniformly upheld to deal with as against to numerous different charges of objection that has been made to.
I say uniformly in the Revenue case in this Court about 253 U.S., two types of the traffic clauses were involved.
One where the (Inaudible) have leased a shipper's railroad from the shipper serving the shipper's coal mine.
And the lease contained the provision that the shipper would ship three fourths of his coal over the leased line and the line of (Inaudible).
The Court said that the claim of violation of the Sherman Act was too insubstantial to be considered.

Other traffic clauses involved in that case were found to be a part of the scheme for the monopolization of the coal of the school fields in Pennsylvania and its transportation to markets, and were condemned as being a part of that scheme of monopolization.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is it common to have in these clauses the provision to ship over the railroad only if it can be considered (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Only if they can't --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If they cannot get better rates of service elsewhere?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's common in all of them?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes that's in everyone.
I should say the words “and service” is not included in grazing leases, it's included in our timber contract or timber cutting contract.
But the administration has at all time recognized that we couldn't expect the shipping business unless we can provide them good service as to our competitor.
And I say that the word “rates being equal” implies service equality because unless the services are the same, you can't compare the rates.

For example, frequently, there may be transit privilege that connects with the rate over one line that isn't available by another to stop privilege that to has appearing on measure of the rate even though the rate itself may be the same number since per hundred pounds.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What happens if the shipper wants the ship to a point that your line is not reached?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: If we can transport it in the direction of movement, if it can be reached by a connection, then we're entitled to the whole as far we can hold.
If he is shipping in a different direction he doesn't need to use our lines.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: He, of course, the shipper would have the right to route to destination from your terminal?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose a wholesale (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: I'm not exactly clear as to what sort of a provision the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose a (Inaudible) that it would sell only to people who would agree to buy all the other products (Inaudible) would that violate the antitrust act?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: I think not necessarily, but I think probably he will get in trouble with Section 3 of the Clayton Act.

Now Section 3 of the Clayton Act is different from Section 1 of Sherman Act and that all that needs to be shown is a potential lessening of competition or a potential tendency to monopoly, whereas, the restraints of the Sherman Act are unlawful only if they're unreasonable and they are unreasonable only if they have actual harmful effects on competition to the detriment result.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Substantial is what you actually mean by that?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Substantial --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Substantial or harmful --

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- effect on competition.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Substantial amount.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Now, on this --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why do you insist that it's not a substantial amount?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Well, we think there's no effect, no substantial effect on competition from this traffic clause.

Because in the first place, our rates have to be published and filed therein, open to all shippers the same -- on the same commodity between the same points for everybody and subject to change only on 30 days notice.

We are in competition in courts for the commodities of all other shippers from the same shipping point, and the -- it is observed to suppose that either our competitors or our self would disregard the business of other shippers because we have clauses that gave us priority on the particular -- of the business with particular shipper.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But it binds the shipper to select you rather than some competitor of yours whose rates maybe the same but whose service condition maybe different, is that right?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes and they frequently do.
They ship by truck, even though they may pay a higher rate but the service is better and it's more economical to them and we recognize --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And this -- this bars that.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: This clause bar such choice by the shipper, does it not?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: I think not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It's not.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: I think not.

I think it is not merely a matter of non-enforcement on our part with a continuing potential for enforcement but it is the practical construction over a long period of years, down to all the shippers of our territory who were subject to these traffic clause.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well I don't understand then what you got if its -- if the shipper have a -- I'm afraid I'm sure I miss -- I misapprehend you.
You say that the shipper is not bound to select this land area.
This shipper is not bound to select you although from the point of view of service he may prefer another line, is that right?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: If he -- if he prefers we have the line because of friendship or reciprocity.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Service preference.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: A preference?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: He is obliged by this clause to ship over our line.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: He has agreed to give us the preference.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So I understand it.
So why isn't -- isn't competition seriously or substantially restrained in that regard that the shipper has no choice by virtue of this clause.
And therefore his freedom of -- of selecting a competitor if the order is cut off, that's the whole point of this (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Well, he -- of course in dealing with that and given these agreements, he does give up his freedom of choice to that extent, that where -- where the choice depends only on considerations of friendship or reciprocity and solicitation where it depends only on those things.
He has agreed to prefer us.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And he is not bound to prefer you if he preferred the services of the other competitors.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: He's not probably preferred us to service the competitors better or if their rates are lower as they often are.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well rates, yes, but where -- where is he free to prefer a competitor of yours who -- which I suppose I would say, which although it charges the same rates, gives more -- gives a preferable service.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: We think he is free to --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He is free?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: To accept that service.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Why?
What -- doesn't this clause bind him against it?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Is it binding?
Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What -- what's the basis for your saying that, although the rates maybe the same over the same distance, the shipper thinks there are service advantages in shipping over a competitor of yours, why is he free to do that in view of this clause?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Because I think that makes a competitor's rate more favorable.

For example, some of the shippers testified that by shipping over to Milwaukee, they -- shipping livestock over to Milwaukee and they could make better time and avoid one stop for feed and rest or unload.
They ship over our line while they have to unload, to feed or rest --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is this --

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: -- additional time.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- is this your construction or is that is what you say without questioning it binding on us as a matter of law, is that -- is that construction, is the government agree to your construction?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Well I think it's a practical construction.

But I would say this Your Honor, there are thousands of these leases or contracts, many of them, a great many of them expressly say, rates, services and facility fee or rates and service fee and the court below treated them all alike, he enjoined all of them and made no difference whether the term services and facility to them or not.
And I say that if there is a distinction, the case should go back to trial on the merit.
Now, I say, we have no intention of making a distinction.
It's just a matter of craftsmanship I suppose drew up the timber contract in the first place since we forgot to put in the word and services.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But that's very important in transportation (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: I think also myself, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Isn't that very important Mr. Countryman?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: I think it's important that the service is just as important as the rates.
And it is not our intention to require the shippers who use our line unless it's a matter of indifference to him which he uses.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, if it's a matter of indifference why would he -- he is to be bound by contact?
What you do, isn't it, is to get balance (Inaudible) agree that they won't trade with another railroad even if they want to because they must (Inaudible).
Now, I understand you say this condition but in the final analysis, if it gets down to it, they can't exercise their freedom of judgment to contract with other railroad even if they desire to do so.
And they do that because you tell them that and tie them down by that validity (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I think that these clauses require us to remain to be always competitive with our competitors if we want to get the business of our lessee.
Now --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It certainly destroys the competition to some extent, does it not, if the man has agreed in advance as the terms is binding as it appears to be that he is not going to buy from another railroad because you sold him some land.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, the shippers who are subject to this clauses are relatively few, I think.
Each ship is important.

There is much other traffic that is identical that is competitive that to -- we must maintain rates and service for, so much to our competitor and I say that the Sherman Act is concerned only with competition as in effect to public.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well I thought we've decided several times that the contracts who violated Sherman Act, restraining a man with his freedom to trade, didn't have to just like everybody (Inaudible) to substantial number of people so as to destroy competition from a substantial number of people located at one place or in any places.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, I don't think your decisions go that far.

I think that the restraints are -- have been held to be per se unreasonable in the absence of any showing as to the actual effect only if they fix prices, represent boycotts or exclude competitors from the substantial bargain.
Now --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But how -- does this exclude competitors to some extent from the right -- the opportunity to get to sell their services to thousands of people?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: I'm not sure that I understand Your Honor's point.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What I meant was does this agreement bar to some extent the freedom of a man to deal with your competitors and does that affect thousands of people depriving the other railroads of the chance to have them exercise their full freedom of choice.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: I don't think it does any more so than if we are able by solicitation to get the business and shipment.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But you have this in addition to solicitation.
The other people are limited to solicitation.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes, I think this is solicitation.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And you have a contract with these thousands of people.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: And I don't think the public is much concerned with solicitation.
I think the Sherman Act is not quite concerned with whether we get the business of a particular shipper or our competitor so long as --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I rather (Voice Overlap) concerned with leading people free to buy and other is free to sell according to their own will and according to their own judgment of what's better at best interest and what they desire to do.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: No I don't think, Your Honor, the Sherman Act goes that far.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If it does go that far, this violates (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes, I would agree.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I thought -- excuse me.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No.
Go on.
I just want to where that clause.
Where is -- where is the clause in the record, the exact terms?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: A number of them are cited in the decision of the trial court on page 186 of the record.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, let me ask you this question basing on 186.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: First one.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, all shipments of livestock et cetera, whenever its freight rates do not exceed the rates of the line.
As I understood you and I want to be sure I did, you said two things.
In the first place, that if a shipper as a mere (Inaudible) out of his own physical relations with officers of the Milwaukee prefers to ship over to Milwaukee.
Not a penny advantage in his pocket but he just likes those officers -- you say under this clause he is allowed to do so.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I say not allowed to do (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Not allowed.
Well, now (Inaudible) -- I notice their difference, is this freight rates (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He can't say, I prefer to ship over the Milwaukee although the rates are the same, can he?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: No.
Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

Now the next question, suppose the services -- suppose he thinks that Milwaukee is faster or allows him more of a stop or one of the other innumerable elements that make up services that that's a more advantageous thing for him from his point of view under the grazing leads, that is not included as a rate, is it?
So you say practically it is.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes, I say that the testimony of our land commissioner the deposition of 17 the grazing lessees all show that that's the way it could interpret (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I put this to you Mr. Countryman, that unless this is an absolutely clear industry construction at all events you will be puzzled and at all event, there will be -- maybe a litigious question there whether the service does include rates and to that extent, the shipper is constrained, you say that it doesn't make any difference to the public.
But I like to put it to you, if I may, that the shipper is part of the public.
You can't say -- when we say restrained competition as against disadvantageously to the public, you can't antithesis the outside public and the class of shippers can you?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I agree with you, and I would say this that I put that object to consent decree of joining us from using this clause unless we put in the word services and facilities.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If you did that, you would still have a right to litigate with every person (Inaudible) and claim damages the amount of the presentation (Inaudible) every time he traded with another railroad.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Even --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How would he ever know at the end of the lawsuit (Inaudible) sometimes a ship without his -- you don't have law (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, we don't sue shippers very often.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, how will you enforce a contract?
That's what I'm curious about, how would you enforce it?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Well, our people who testified that the main value of it is the assistance to the solicitor that matters agree.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may I ask (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, go ahead.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Mr. Countryman, I -- from my understanding of the principle points you argue in the brief which you haven't here discussed at all, deals with the basis upon which the trial court rested its decision.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Namely, that as the Government here concedes apparently by its brief, there was no evidence of any monopoly by your railroad or the land market.

And the trial court said as a matter of law, it was not necessary to show that you did have any monopoly of the land market, it was enough alone that title to the particular piece of real estate was invested in fee in the railroad.
Now is that correct or not?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Well, I wanted to argue that point, Your Honor but I think my time has expired.
We disagree sharply on whether mere ownership of land and just to ownership of the piece of land with monopolistic result.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: But one -- one section of land, the court said -- the trial court said, if the Railroad has titled to that we're not concerned with any monopoly in any market of land.
But it is enough if he own -- that the railroad owns title to the one piece of real estate, and that's the basis of the decision, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I think the court is entirely wrong.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What -- why is that the basis of the decision?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Because the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What difference does that make suppose it wasn't a land, suppose this is a contract unrelated to the land relation of the -- of the railroad, and they just got out of the goodness of their heart for self interest, makes such an agreement, would that be alright?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, aren't we entitled to go out and make contract to shippers for one transportation or have the transportation?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Whereby the shipper binds himself not to use a rival -- a competing railroad?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You are?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes, of the Great Western case in this Court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I didn't understand that.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Interstate Commerce Commission against Great Western Railroad.
The Rock Island Railroads -- no the Great Western Railroad put on a reduce rate, a published rate for the shippers of packing house products in Missouri River markets.
And in consideration of the Great Western publishing that reduced rate, the packers agreed to give the Great Western three fourths of all their business.
And it was enforced to this Court.
It was attacked and a violation of the antitrust law.
This Court said, railroads are free to have a business the same as others and the big contracts looking into the entries of their business.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What -- what is that case, Mr. Countryman?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Chicago Great Western Railway Company against the Interstate Commerce Commission -- the Interstate Commerce Commission against the Great Western, 209 U.S.108.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How did that came up, in the Sherman or Government?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: That was Sherman Act case, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: It was not as -- it was not an enforcement of the Sherman Act, it was a proceeding before the Interstate Commerce Commission where the question of violation of the Sherman Act was involved.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't see that the Interstate Commerce Commission has any authority to involve Sherman --

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: No, it was not an enforcement proceeding either by a judge in the criminal proceeding.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you say that you -- it's your understanding that the construction of Sherman law applicable that is to the railroads arrangements, that is the shipper of consideration that he deem appropriate, I don't care what it is.
For the next two years bind himself because railroad X assures him that they will always have cut.
That he can make an agreement that for the next two years he will never use any competing service.
You think that's alright under the Sherman law?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Now, we have to say the case --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not denying it.
I'm a little surprised.
That's all.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Well, we have enforcement to -- of such contract against St.Paul and Tacoma Lumber Company.
It is cited in here, decision by the Eighth Circuit.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr.-- Mr. Countryman, isn't the mere fact that you have millions of acres of land that cannot be opened up to settlement and development unless they make agreements with you that they will not use the services of any of your competitors, a restraint to some kind on your competition and therefore on commerce?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: I don't think so, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, you've got -- you check a board this -- this country for ten miles on each side of your right of way, every order in this section belongs to railroad.

Now if you can -- you can prevent any of that land from being opened up to development and settlement until the purchasers agree with you that they will use services of no competitors, do you not think that that places some burden on your competitors in developing the service that will be as -- as good or as cheap as yours?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Well, I might say this, Your Honor, while we were using these traffic clauses, the (Inaudible) Railway built west to the Pacific Coast in 1893.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Milwaukee built west in 1907.

The Panama Canal was opened, the ship line operated through the canal, highways come in, truck lines, the contract carriers -- common carrier, motor trucks, private carriers on the highways has come in to the Pacific.
It's a pretty --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, but that might have been in spite of your -- your policies and not because of it.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: I think it's rather indicative of the fact that our clauses have not suppressed competition.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, they might be -- they might prevent competition or at least suppress competition and still not be great enough force to prevent those great things from happening.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, 37 million acres of this land has been sold and almost all of it without any traffic clauses.
What we have left are scattered remnants and only part of those were subject to traffic clauses.
Now the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But I suppose if you can do it for some --

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: -- the grazing land --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- you can do it for all, couldn't you?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: The grazing lands are open at all times to sale without a traffic clause.
We only lease them pending sale and we only put the traffic clause in lease.
We don't put it in the -- in the contract -- in the sales.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You're not claiming here as I understand that this complaint should be dismissed.
You're claiming that you're entitled to trial?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: That's it, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is that it?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: That's exactly the point.
The question is whether the summary judgment was properly granted.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: In other words, you insist upon trial an opportunity to be heard upon the question of whether or not there is a contract or combination or conspiracy that was strange trade in this market, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: That's exactly the point, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: But the trial court didn't place it upon -- he said that the government was entitled to the judgment it received simply upon a finding that you had the simple title to a particular section of land, is that right?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well not on that abstract proposition but because you have the simple title and therefore could dispose of the transfer of that title and made the condition of transfer on getting the business that on its faith shows that the shipper -- the shipping public was constrained in the choice that was open to it in selecting its carrier, isn't that it?
Have I stated the case fairly?

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: I don't think that it's a proof of compulsion that they entered into this contract.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well compulsion in the nature of things that if a fellow said you can't get my land unless you promise to send stuff over my line that that necessarily is an inducement for shipment unrelated to the mere fact of the service rendered.

turn.speaker: ml_countryman_jr
turn.label: Mr. M.L. Countryman Jr.
turn.text: Suppose the situation is the other way, Your Honor and we're out trying to sell our land to purchasers or to lease it to, he's not coming to us, we are trying to sell it to him.
And that is a question of fact in the Court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Friedman.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

The contract restrictions which are involved in this case are ones which basically give the Northern Pacific Railway Company a claim, the right to get the business of the shippers to whom it has sold or leased various categories of its land, as long as the Northern Pacific's rates and in some instances, the service are equal.
Mr. Countryman has suggested that it's a practical matter this case must be treated as though rates and service were written into all of these contracts.
The fact is that they're not written into all of these contracts.

The contracts vary in their form but the contracts which cover the majority of the acreage involved in this case are limited to rates and do not authorize a shipper to ship via some competing carrier merely because the service is better either in his opinion or in the Northern Pacific's opinion.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What do you say to his reediness to have the decree modified so that there could be no doubt on that subject?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: In our opinion, Mr. Justice, that would not be the end of this case.
We think even assuming that service and rates are covered in all of these contracts, these agreements will nevertheless be bad.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, should we -- would you think it was appropriate to argue the case on the assumption that the decree is so verified?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If it doesn't make any difference then nothing can save it, but if it does make a difference, then his readiness of the decree is modified, it doesn't make a difference (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well, I'm not -- still not clear as to whether you mean by that that he concedes and in all instances, every one of these contracts applies to rates and service.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's what --

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: We --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- I'm assuming to indicate to be ready to have a decree modified to read.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Even if the decree was so modified, we still would not be satisfied.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Because we think --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In other words, you said it does not make any difference, so no use of -- of accepting his modification.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: The -- in any event, if a shipper for whatever reason as a matter of whimsy as Your Honor suggested, wishes to patronize a competing carrier, we think, he has the right to do that.
Now, I'd like to mention one other thing in describing these restraints.
In some instances, they go beyond merely requiring the lessee or the grantee to ship the products produced on a particular land.
In some instances, they're acquiring to ship products produced not only on the lands received from Northern Pacific but on adjacent lands in the same area which he then or thereafter own.
And indeed in some of the leases, leases for the coal lands, there's a provision requiring him to ship incoming freight destined to those areas by the Northern Pacific.
Now --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does all of that make any difference or premise of the antitrust law?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No it doesn't, Mr. Justice, but this, I think, is significant in showing the bold anti-competitive purpose of these particular clauses.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, if -- if you argue as to the anti-competitive purposes within argument a part from the document then Justice Whittaker's question becomes relevant.
That's a matter for determination and not a matter for legal assumption on a summary judgment.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well, I would suggest Mr. Justice that on their face --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: These agreements --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Very well.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: -- are designed solely to exclude competitor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I understand that if you make that argument, but if you talk about intention then intention can be -- is an issue of controversy.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I like to suggest to point out to the Court that unlike some of the tying situations where there is a claim at least, the agreement may be necessary to protect the goodwill of a seller, for example, the claim by International Salt Company that international salt was not used in the machines, the machines will not operate properly, the claim by International Business Machines Company that any other clause do not permit the machine to function if there's only -- there is no possible claim of that kind in this case.

In this case, you have land which is sold or leased and there's no possible argument that these restrictive clauses are needed to permit the more efficient use or the better use of the remaining land which Northern Pacific has.
This is a --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Supposing -- supposing that Northern Pacific had one part of land and it made a deal with the purchaser saying, "I'll sell you this land if you ship over our land” rates being equal by using that land, is that bad under the antitrust law?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That would depend, Mr. Justice, upon how substantial a volume of commerce was affected.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: If the Northern Pacific leased an enormous track and say General Motors and General Motors ship many millions of dollars worth of product over (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Assuming -- assuming that the volume of commerce is substantial, is that all you've got to show under Section 1?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Where they are or in the position, Mr. Justice to impose this agreement.
I believe so.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, when you say and suppose the agreements, you're talking about some showing monopoly power?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Monopoly power?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Don't you concede in this case that you have to show two things under Section 1.
Number one, that is a substantial effect on the market.
And number two that as far as the tying matter was concerned with the land that the -- there was a leverage there which the Northern Pacific had and could exercise to bring about this restraint.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: We suggest Mr. Justice that this case maybe approached on two different theories.

The theory which you have suggested is the theory of the tying cases enunciated in the Times-Picayune case and I will come to that in a moment and believe what -- show why I believe we have established that.

But we think this particular situation has a further vice, this is a situation in which you have contracts which on their face show no demonstrable business purpose, no legitimate business aim and the effect of them is to preclude competing sellers of transportation from any access to a very substantial market.

In other words, it narrows the outlet as this Court have said of competing sellers and at the same time denies to the use of the transportation their freedom to patronize competing carriers and that we think that where you have that kind of a situation whether it's on a wide scale and whether it's a substantial restraint of interstate commerce, the principles which this Court has applied in such cases and associated press and fashion originated skill, compel the conclusion that these agreements are invalid on their face.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Let me -- let me vary the case put to you by my brother Harlan.

Suppose the -- the railroad says, the Northern Pacific advertises or makes known that it will sell some of its fee for X dollars per acre, but it will sell it for X minus Y dollars per acre if the purchaser agrees to shift his products over to Northern Pacific.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Mr. Justice, I would suggest that the railroad can't do that because of the Elkins Act because I think they will be giving a concession to one shipper over another.
They're providing the identical transportation service to two shippers.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Not at all.
They're having different rates for a piece of land.
Anyhow, put the Elkins Act aside because I'm having so difficulty.
What would you say under the Sherman law?
Will that be better under Sherman law, the case I put you?
They're in the market and they sell land as the Northern Pacific was and they have two prices, forget about the Elkins Act for the moment, would that be violating the Sherman law?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I would think so.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You would think so?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now, may I ask you Mr. Friedman, is there any finding by the court below that the Northern Pacific did have any monopoly on the real estate market or in that area?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, Mr. Justice.
There's no finding that they had monopoly of all the lands in the area.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Or monopoly in the market.
Didn't the Court simply say that that wasn't essential to his conclusion?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That -- that is correct because the Court says if the --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now, isn't it true that in the Sherman Act case, there has to be some monopolization of the market that restraints competition?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I don't think so Mr. Justice.
I think in the tying situations or --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Isn't that what the Times-Picayune case held, the Dupont case recently?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I respectfully don't think so Mr. Justice.
I think that if we start with the International Salt case, if I may refer to that briefly for a moment.

That was a case in which the salt company leased patented machines and as a condition to the lease of the machines, the lessees were required to use in the machine the salt manufactured by the International Salt Company.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: There was no showing in that case as to what percentage of the market for the tying product, that is, the salt leasing machine International Salt had.
Despite this, the District Court granted summary judgment, and this Court upheld the grant of summary judgment.
Now, in their appeal to this Court, International Salt challenged the ruling of the trial court because they said they're entitled to show that there were competing machines.
That in fact competitors were not excluded, and furthermore, they said they're entitled to show what percentage of the market, the salt machines they had.

And this Court deemed those considerations irrelevant and then subsequently in the Standard Oil case, this Court in discussing the International Salt case pointed out that those factors were present in that case and they were deemed irrelevant.
Now --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Can you think of case off hand that a person has been found guilty of violating antitrust law, shown to have a complete monopoly?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I cannot think of any case.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The Standard Oil Company had a complete monopoly.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No.
The Standard Oil Company had --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The (Voice Overlap) originated here?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Roughly 60%.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The International Salt?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: The International Salt, the Court deemed it irrelevant.
We don't know what percent of that.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Well, can you think of any case where there maybe some.
I was just stating what I think of where anyone group that ever get perhaps the advantage -- got hold of the flower once (Inaudible) where anyone had a complete monopoly over the (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Suppose in some situations involving a unique patented article which was so distinct from any other, there might be a situation, I don't know of any such case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't think the order relied too much on International Salt because the determining consideration there was within abuse of the patent and that goes a long way.
I'm not saying -- all I'm saying is that if that's all you have to rest on, I'd like to hear more argument in this (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well, I think Mr. Justice that even though in International Salt, the company had abuse its patents by seeking to go beyond its patent monopoly.

That factor, I don't believe was crucial on the question of whether International Salt had the recusant dominance to be able to effectively enforce upon its lessees the obligation to purchase the tied product.

And what we're saying to this Court is that the kind of leverage which a patent holder is able to exert in a situation where there may be very many other articles, very similar which will do the same thing is comparable to the kind of leverage which the owner of land is able to exert as we think it's shown here by the fact that these people were able to impose these contracts upon their lessees and grantee.
Now, in this situation--

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: May I ask though, isn't that a factual situation and has -- as to whether or not the Northern Pacific did have such control over the market as to be able to restrain commerce and isn't that an issue of fact which they wanted to try but didn't get an opportunity to try in the court below?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I don't think so Mr. Justice, anymore than there was an issue of fact in the International Salt case as to whether the salt company's particular patented salt machine nevertheless represented such a minor share of the market that in fact they didn't have monopoly power.
I don't think that it's necessary in a Section 1 case of this type to show that they have monopoly power in the sense of a violation of Section 2 of the Sherman Act law.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Would you mind stating?
It hasn't been stated and I think these questions ultimately would be wise to state it.
I do not think that the summary judgment should be used every time a judge (Inaudible) to use it when he gets submissions of fact.
Would you mind stating what are the admitted issues of facts in this case on which the Court rests its summary judgment.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: The admitted facts in this case are that the Northern Pacific Railway Company has sold or leased a substantial volume of land.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How about just approximate?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Certainly several million acres, two or three million.
It varies from things --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Located where?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Located in six western states.
The further fact --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What -- over what period?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Dated back 50 or 60 years and the leases in the record are as recent as 1946 and 1947 I think.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Are the recent -- are the recent sales or leases in acreage sizeable?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Or the sizeable -- the sizeable acreage owns that?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I haven't made that analysis of the record but there are at the time this suit was filed, there was a sizeable acreages covered by the leases.
It's a very elaborate breakdown in the record of each lease and the amount of acreage involved.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How much land does it have left, do you happen to know?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Except for the right of way, it's 2,700,000 acres out of the total land grant of some 39 million.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is that farming section mainly where the property has been sold or was it grazing or farming?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: A lot of it is grazing.
The two major items are the grazing leases and some of the grazing land has been sold and the timber leases.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It had been sold in large block as numbers of each according to the fact that you have in your record.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: It's been sold to a large number of people.
It doesn't -- coming through this -- the acreage varies tremendously.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And were there shipper from centers?
Shippers who did not have lease or fee holdings from the Northern Pacific in the -- in the centers from which these shipments were made?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That is not shown by the record, but I -- in view of their contention that they had only a very small portion of the lands involved.
I think we have to assume there are shippers but I'd like to point out --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Because if you -- if that is so, you put a thought in my mind that if the case I put to you is an Elkins Act case, I should think all these things (Inaudible) violations.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: The time -- return to the other agreed upon the facts in this case that in the sale and lease of these lands, Northern Pacific imposed covenants requiring the lessee or grantee to ship exclusively via Northern Pacific if the rates and in some instances the services were equal.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is there any dispute over there?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I don't believe so.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is that conceded or stipulated?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I believe that is not challenged.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Covering large numbers?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Yes, that is -- I -- there is a question as to whether it covers rates and service or rate.
There is no dispute as to that.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Are there any figures Mr. Friedman of the volume of traffic by shippers who have this kind of statutory in their agreement?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, Mr. Justice, all there is is a showing of the generally substantial volume of land covered and there is a stipulation in the record at page 99 that the information to the particular shipments, by particular shipments, is either not available to the defendant or cannot be furnished by the defendant without excessive expense and without consuming an unwarranted length of time.
There is nothing in the record to show the precise dollar value of shipments affected by these traffic clauses.
There is, however, the finding by the Court that a substantial volume of commerce moved in interstate commerce which was -- came off the land subject to these clauses.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, do I understand you to say that the aggregate of the acreage presently subject to these clauses is in the neighborhood of 2,700,000 or something?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, the 2,700,000 figure is the amount of acreage which Northern Pacific still holds.

The contracts which were enforced in 1949 when this complaint was filed as set forth in -- at series of detailed findings, 13 to 35 at record 203 to 208, and they're roughly about 2,200,000 or 2,300,000.
Those are the contracts at the time of the suit that were covered by these rulings.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well now would that be 2,300,000 out of the retained holdings of about 2,700,000, is that it?
Isn't -- didn't I understand that all of it about 2,700,000 or 2,800,000 acres had already been sold by the railroad?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That is correct but of this amount, roughly, more than a million acres are timberland sales where the land has been sold as I -- in other words, some of the land has been sold.
Now there's a million acres of that and then there's roughly a 1,200,000 acres that has been leased and 1,200,000 should properly subtracted by the 2,700,000 -- from the 2,700,000.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is there any concentration or does it appear in -- mentioned I think you said that this was distributed over several states?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Any one or more state, two states where most of it is or is it pretty widely distributed?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: It doesn't show in those terms.
There's no findings as to where and what state in particular.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well it is actually in Minnesota, Dakota, Montana, is it not?
Do you know?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: I do not know the precise areas where these lands are located.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Has there been any departure from stipulation which it made with reference to the volume of shipments in interstate commerce, the lessee from land (Inaudible) land covered by these leases on page 99 to page 120.
Has there been any -- is that still the agreement, is that the agreement with the -- did the Court have that agreement for that stipulation of a fact?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Yes, it did.
The stipulation is a substantial portion that there's -- I say there's no particular breakdown as to the precise dollar volumes from each individual shipper or from particular --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And that shows that would have been very expensive and I gather you'd say --

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: In fact stipulated --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- selected lessees from shipments under each various stations along the line?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: There wasn't -- basically, I would say a recognition -- a concession of substantial shipments were involved.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That stipulation (Inaudible) would mean, I just understand that the counsel for the railroad (Inaudible) in fact that there was substantial amount of volume (Inaudible).
I do not understand what -- what issues of the fact they had the court to decide or did they -- what was that issue of fact?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: The issue of fact, they wanted the Court to determine primarily was whether in fact Northern Pacific had a dominant position in all the particular types of lands involved.
In other words they --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You took the position that was given to you?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So did the Court?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That's correct.

They -- they wanted the Court to say whether in grazing lands in Montana which Northern Pacific leased whether in fact Northern Pacific had a dominant position in the sense of having 60% or 70% and whether it only had 5% or 10%, we took the position that that was immaterial.

We said that the impact of these clauses was such and the fact that they have this position as the owners of the land and were able to exert leverage sufficient to get the shippers or the grantees to enter into these contracts that that was enough to violate the Sherman Act.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The fact that they were able to exert leverage is essential if contracts are made or discover a substantial part of interstate commerce, suppose they're made voluntarily between the parties.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well this was --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What difference does it make so far as the violation of the antitrust act --

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: As we rate the International Salt case, we don't think it does make any difference but if the -- under the Times-Picayune case where it speaks in terms of exerting monopolistic leverage, we believe we -- as an alternative theory meet that test because they were able to exert that leverage in this case through the possession of their land.

But we think there's a broader position and the situation involved here which is that they have tied up a substantial volume of commerce and with respect to that volume of commerce, they have excluded a --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose the a three steel company manufactured 35% of the steel of the country that would combine voluntarily either one being authorized to exert some kind of a power.
They just decided they want to combine or fix grievance agreement between (Inaudible) would that not violate the Sherman Act?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Clearly Mr. Justice, it would violate the Sherman Act because there was a substantial -- it was a restraint on a substantial volume of commerce.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Friedman, counsel often tell us the things of interest by way of background.

Well, the judges also have that curiosity at times and I have the curiosity of -- curiosity to ask you whether this record shows what blew -- what can this litigation is being in 1949 when this is a long standing arrangement on the part of the Northern Pacific.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Now, the record --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Anything in the record on that?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: There's nothing --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is there something that's on 50 to 60 years?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No.

There's nothing in the record on that Mr. Justice, and I frankly don't know what was the emphasis to this litigation except that I supposed that it's conceivable that with a limited step of the antitrust division, we never got around to doing it until this time.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But the record doesn't show that something from new -- of course effort or anything like that is made by the railroad.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, it does not Mr. Justice.
And in conclusion, I just like to point out once again that these agreements have no demonstrable business purpose.
They're solely anticompetitive.

They're designed solely to give Northern Pacific a priority on this business and we believe that affecting as they do a substantial volume of commerce and narrowing the outlets to which competing sellers may sell and from which purchase of transportation they buy, they're invalid and that it is not necessary in holding them invalid to establish if Northern Pacific in fact had any dominance of all the lands in the area.
Thank you.
